sources.title: The Train (1964)
sources.description: The Train is a 1964 action war film directed by John Frankenheimer and starring Burt Lancaster, Paul Scofield and Jeanne Moreau. Set  during World War II, French Resistance member Paul Labiche must stop a German colonel, Franz von Waldheim, from transporting stolen art masterpieces out of France by train. As the Allies approach Paris, Labiche and his team devise clever strategies to delay the train without damaging the valuable cargo, ultimately leading to a tense confrontation.

sources.title: The Train (1964) Burt Lancaster · Jeanne Moreau
sources.description: During the occupation of France, valuable paintings are to be transported to Germany by train. The film depicts the resistance movement's efforts to prevent the transport. It is more interested in creating suspense than in exploring the conflicts in depth. With its technically perfect, sober style, the film deserves attention.

metadata.Plot: As the Allied forces approach Paris in August 1944, German Colonel Von Waldheim is desperate to take all of France's greatest paintings to Germany. He manages to secure a train to transport the valuable art works even as the chaos of retreat descends upon them. The French resistance however wants to stop them from stealing their national treasures but have received orders from London that they are not to be destroyed. The station master, Labiche, is tasked with scheduling the train and making it all happen smoothly but he is also part of a dwindling group of resistance fighters tasked with preventing the theft. He and others stage an elaborate ruse to keep the train from ever leaving French territory.
metadata.Writer: Franklin Coen, Frank Davis, Rose Valland
metadata.Actors: Burt Lancaster, Paul Scofield, Jeanne Moreau
metadata.Awards: Nominated for 1 Oscar. 1 win & 3 nominations total
